subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Anchoring Bias: The Power of First Numbers
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Anchoring Bias: The Power of First Numbers.

hook.text: A VC asked for a startup's valuation. The founder said $10 million. Every negotiation orbited that number.

buildup.text: Anchoring bias means the first piece of information we hear dominates all subsequent judgment.

discovery.text: In negotiations, whoever names a number first sets the anchor. Everything else adjusts around it.

twist.text: Even experts fall for it. Experienced VCs adjust from anchors rather than calculating value independently.

climax.text: Steve Jobs anchored the iPad launch at $999â€”then revealed $499. It felt like a steal. It was the plan.

punchline.text: The first number you hear is the hardest to forget.

quiz.question: How does anchoring bias affect startup negotiations?
options: The first number mentioned disproportionately influences the final outcome
It causes founders to undervalue their companies
